These "compositional" reasons were a significant factor in average wage growth during the pandemic, but that is no longer the case. (In fact, in the most recent figures, compositional factors were a drag on average earnings.) More at https://t.co/ShotkXI2OO https://t.co/D1GxLSqeyt

It's fairly simple to understand: if people at the lowest end of the earnings scale lose their jobs, but people at the top don't, the _average_ wage goes up despite no one being paid more than before. 2/3

A big reason for the rise in _average_ wages during the pandemic lockdown was simply that there were fewer jobs around for those with low skills, and in traditionally low-skilled economic sectors 1/3 https://t.co/Vgv2E6369W

I've written about this in the context of Andy Burnham winning powers to regulate the GM bus network here - and pointed out the big increase in bus use in London came with an injection of money, and not because London was protected from deregulation. [9/9] https://t.co/8y2iQQVkjy

Anyway, for me, levelling up has to including providing (central) funding to promote economic development which aims to create more robust, flourishing local economies where local taxes _do_ make more sense. [8/9]
Would Manchester hike its council tax by 70% to create parity with Barnet - and a major new revenue stream - if it had the power to do so? Of course not. People couldn't afford to pay. [7/9]

But council tax is based largely on property values, and most properties in Manchester are worth much less than most properties in Barnet. The average council tax paid per dwelling in Manchester will be ¬£1,042
. In Barnet it will be ¬£1,731. [6/9]

Look at council tax bills for example. These are often quoted on a Band D basis. On that basis, Manchester's Band D council tax will be ¬£1,873 for 2022/23. In Barnet - which pursued aggressive outsourcing to cut council tax bills - Band D bills will be ¬£1,746. [5/9]

Take somewhere like Manchester - seen as something as a poster-child for economic growth. Yes, it's developing a health tax base in terms of city centre businesses. But that doesn't make it a rich city. [4/9]
"Fine, so let's have more local tax raising powers". How much money is there to tax? If there's so much, why do places need to be "levelled up" in the first place? [3/9]
Having power to make and implement local strategy is important: but power without _money_ is likely only to scratch the surface of what needs to be done. [2/9]

Been thinking a lot recently about how "local devolution" is often accepted - on all political sides - as something of a panacea for regional inequality, a major lever to "level up", etc. A thread! [1/9]

Overall, "the gap in avoidable mortality between the most and least deprived areas widened to its highest level since 2004 for males, and highest since the data began in 2001 for females", says Chris White, head of health inequalities at the Office for National Statistics.

@CharlotteGRose Yep - I think that has been a great initiative, and I know some really excellent LDR reporters.
@thomasforth Absolutely - or that it might be that doing the former might increase their ability to do the latter.

I don't have any easy solutions to any of this. I don't believe they exist. I do believe local news remains vital, that there are brilliant and highly-committed people working in the industry, and that there aren't obvious villains here.

In a situation where a small number of people pay for subscription-based news services that cover a limited range of stories that matter to them and are perfectly happy, I worry about the other people: the majority who won't or can't pay. Where are they getting their news?

True "clickbait" headlines - where the story doesn't deliver on the promise of the headline - are less common than you'd think, and organisations know they are counter-productive in the long term. Headlines which slightly oversell or under-inform are much more common.

It _is_ true that a lot of what I'd consider important public-interest news is a tough sell to mass audiences. It's also true that a lot of purely informational stuff that gets sneered at (X opening a new shop in Y, "what time is x", "how do I why?") is valuable to readers.

It _isn't_ generally the case that the most ridiculous, terrible, sensationalist stories get the highest traffic. In my time high-quality, reliable, timely coverage of big breaking stories did best. Local election results did ridiculously well, too.

Actually wanting big audiences for your stories isn't, in and of itself, a bad thing. On the contrary. What we want is the biggest audiences for the highest-quality news, the most important stories. We want informed communities!

"Just move to a subscription model! I'd pay loads for quality journalism!" News at scale is expensive! Even the best proponents (and there are some excellent ones!) remain small, often still rely on grants and donations, and can't comprehensively cover a city or region.

We should at least acknowledge this might be an us (the audience) problem as well as a them (the news providers) problem. Perhaps there simply aren't enough of us to make the kind of news coverage we say we want a viable proposition.

If your local newspaper survived (and thrived) as a website covering nothing but football, would it be morally bad? Or neutral? What if it occasionally did public-interest investigations, too? Neutral-good?

From an observer/audience point of view: when you say chasing bigger audiences is a bad strategy, bad for whom? Do news organisations have a moral obligation to cover the stories you think are important, even if they don't generate sufficient readers to be economically viable?

If you are going to base your business model on free content - maximising advertising revenue, sponsored content, first-party data, etc - you are going to need _huge_ audiences, and ideally loyal ones, too.

You need some consistent account of what do we value, and why, and how much? Is a two-month investigation that sends a crooked politician to jail worth more, less or the same as a load of consumer stories that generate 10m page views? This is a moral and financial balancing act.

In other words if you think some stories have a value beyond mere "PVs per hour spent" - if this is something you talk about and which benefits your brand - you really need to try to capture that in your targets. That's hard.

What is unreasonable is failing to take into account all the relevant factors: if you write about local councils, or do long time-consuming investigations, the expectations have to be quite different to those for e.g. a trends writer.

The detail here is very important. If there are targets that individual titles must hit in order to sustain jobs, it's not prima facie unreasonable to give individual journalists an indication of their share of those targets.

I completely understand the objections to this and I'm well aware of the drawbacks of any free/"volume" model for journalism. However, I think some of the responses are wilfully blind to complex issues. A few lunchtime thoughts...

I remember interviewing David Cameron about this when he was PM, and getting a strong sense he didn't really grasp the details and was a bit baffled someone would be that exercised about it (I was pol ed for the Manchester Evening News at the time).

This went under-remarked because local government funding is complex, and local government is unfashionable (until you need social care, or education, or libraries, or youth centres, or playing fields, or...)
Council tax is locally-raised, of course, and cuts have hit urban (generally poorer) councils harder. So local people in poorer areas have part-subsidised enormous central government cuts.

People don't appreciate the scale of local government cuts since 2010. National Audit Office found councils' "spending power" fell 28.6% to 2017/18; if you removed council tax the figure was 49.1%, or basically half. [1/2]

I think some national coverage of Manchester's housing market is based on a misunderstanding: the city centre was never really somewhere people lived. The problem is less the explosion of flats there; more how that money is (or isn't) leveraged into affordable housing elsewhere

By the time the December lockdown was announced cases had been rising sharply for two weeks; the virus was running out of control and this led directly to the UK having the highest death rate in the world during January. (6/6) https://t.co/312g6u0xoE

The third - which is in some ways the least forgivable, because we knew so much by then - was the decision to keep non-essential shops open under the December tiers. This was in the run-up to Christmas! And obscured by talk of "tough" tiers and "cancelling Christmas week". (5/6)
The second was emptying hospitals into care homes, and failing to even try to then make sure those care homes were biosecure. (4/6)

The UK was around two weeks behind e.g. Italy in what was happening. We had a chance to learn the tragic lessons of others in real time, and act accordingly. Instead there was dither and stasis. (3/6)

The first - which Cummings is alluding to - is the time it took for the first lockdown. We were slow to act at a time when deaths were rising. And - crucially - we had already _seen_ what was happening elsewhere, and the consequences of being slow to act. (2/6) https://t.co/s7jymtxbd6

I accept governing in a rapidly-changing crisis situation is hard for the most well-organised, functional administration. But when I think of the UK government's response I always come back to three errors which are hard to forgive. (1/6)

(/5 was optimistic, looking back.)

These figures - which should be _crucial_ to shaping our local response, and our opinions as citizens - are therefore relegated to a point where they are of nothing but historic interest. And yet they exist!

Instead all I can tell you now is the critical-care occupancy rates that _did_ exist each day in September in each hospital trust in Greater Manchester. I won't know about October until the middle of November.

This matters: if we are going to have local responses to Covid then we need local data to determine what is right or wrong. For instance: a key issue now is whether Manchester's hospitals are at risk of being overwhelmed, and I should be able to judge for myself using local data.
I'd also argue that the decision to stop publishing neighbourhood-level case data makes it harder for us to judge what is happening where we live. 4/5
Previously, we were getting _some_ testing data but so much of it was missing that what we did have was virtually useless 3/5
Currently we have pretty timely hospital data on Covid admissions, critical-care occupancy etc at a national or regional level, but not at a local (or city-regional) level. 2/5

There's actually been a decent amount of timely, local, useful Covid-19 data put out by bodies like the ONS, NHS England, government depts etc. The problem is the data we don't get is often precisely the data we need, e.g. 1/5

It's a reasonable discussion to have. People are going to suffer whichever course we choose. These are horrible, difficult choices and I wish the tone of the debate reflected that more.

The correct way to respond is: "Didn't work compared to what?" There's no magic bullet solution. Either we let numbers spiral and accept the deaths that follow (and the strain on critical capacity), or we face on/off restrictions which will sometimes be onerous.

The fact is if we want to bring case numbers down, here and elsewhere, tougher restrictions will be necessary. I don't understand people saying "But lockdown didn't work! The disease came back!" What do you expect "working" to look like?

So a couple of things leap out when I use our neighbourhood Covid tracker with my own postcode: 1) my LSOA (Prestwich Central) has somehow dodged high numbers; 2) local "lockdown" measures haven't done much to stem the tide across Bury as a whole.  https://t.co/Ta7kd9uUO3 https://t.co/zpXzCD45kR

@danwainwright Testing + track/trace are vital but only if that data is then put to best use! For me that involves not just local authorities being genuinely involved, but local populations being well informed, too. Getting ahead of the virus needs to be a team effort.

@danwainwright I'm not sure people generally are monitoring the (local) data now as closely as they monitored the (national/international) data during the first few weeks. Yet in some ways it's even more crucial that they do. (It didn't help that the figures weren't initially shared.)

I believe local authorities should have been much more involved in local monitoring & decision making from the start. But there should also be clear (& clearly communicated) guidance on what constitutes an actionable local outbreak so people and economies can prepare/avoid

The spikes in Greater Manchester, while not huge, are significant. Our ability to identify, act on and quash these local outbreaks will determine how we all get to live in the weeks and months ahead.  https://t.co/Au3BO8IcGQ

@thomasforth Absolutely - plus (I'd guess) more time for relevant authorities to prepare. And greater awareness presumably = more more compliance, and less resentment.

@thomasforth The interesting thing about the GM daily data is that it's been obvious for a few days that it's been looking a bit iffy. But no one really talks about the daily data (even as a rolling average); and no one knows the 'rules', ie when the great finger will emerge from the clouds..
There are many reasons England was slow to stem the tide of Covid and suffered rapid geographic spread. But I'm fairly sure our hugely centralised decision making system was one of them.
Local authorities had to prise up-to-date and accurate testing data from the government but now they have it: what's the point if there is no coordinated decision making that involves them all?
Local lockdowns are likely to be the new normal for a long time to come; it's not like we can become a devolved country overnight but we have to do better than this.

We should have properly informed and empowered local authorities making decisions on local Covid measures. Instead we get a botched top-down muddle with three hours notice, where many of those authorities seem as confused as the rest of us.

This one‚Ä¶

Band D relates to historic house prices and isn't in any way adjusted to different property types or markets around the country. So Liverpool has the same band D rate as Waverley, but raises half as much per property, because most of its homes are actually Band A.

Another council tax bugbear: comparing councils by Band D  rate ignores that many cities have few properties in Band D or above 
Band D in Liverpool: ¬£2,027 
Band D in Waverley, Surrey: ¬£2,031.
That translates to ¬£1,029 per _actual dwelling_ in Liverpool and ¬£2,130 in Waverley.

(PS would be nice to get some slightly more detailed data from the Covid-19 rough sleeping programme! At the moment the screenshot above is literally all we've been given. A single figure for London and a figure for everywhere else.) https://t.co/PMQEeXhWAM
Now we know more rough sleepers (or people at risk of rough sleeping) have been provided emergency accommodation _in London_ than we were told there were rough sleepers in the whole of England.
We've always known the official count - which is simply a co-ordinated count on a single night in autumn - isn't really fit for capturing the true scale of rough sleeping.

Last official "rough sleeper" count found 4,266 people sleeping rough in England. Figures out today show 14,610 people sleeping rough or at risk of sleeping rough have been given emergency accommodation as a result of Covid-19. https://t.co/uXbw2HAKk6

We've been moving towards a system where even core council services like social care, child protection, libraries and suchlike are seen as local matters to be paid for locally, rather than national priorities where richer areas effectively subside poorer ones according to need

There are two things going on here: a cut in central funds to councils, partially covered by raising more cash from local people in the form of council tax. Take e.g. Leeds (and Leeds is somewhere which is _relatively_ able to pay its own way) 
https://t.co/VV7yYpLaUA https://t.co/SPFUndJRMm

This is devolution of a sort: devolving responsibility for dealing with austerity. It is certainly not progressive: areas in greater need of council services, and whose residents have a lower ability to pay, are being told to stump up cash or continue to cut

Non-Covid news. Council tax figures out this morning show 20 out of 25 counties, 28 of 33 London boroughs, 25 of 36 Metropolitan districts and 40 out of 57 unitary councils have put council tax up by the maximum 3.99% for 2020/21. Local taxpayers are subsiding Treasury cuts.

@lowwintersun That's a very good point.

There were 76 Covid-19 deaths of (male) cab drivers in the dataset. The virus accounted for nearly _half_ of all deaths among working age cab drivers over that time. These are people that have no choice but to work, who others _expect_ to work.

As evidence this is about exposure, not just demographics - here are Covid death rates for different types of driver. It's the "exposed" ones - taxi/bus drivers - who are dying. These are key workers. These are people risking their lives. https://t.co/E6Eids6p8u

(This is something that really annoyed me about that "Brexit voters are ignoring lockdown and still going to the workplace!" narrative from a while ago. Real story is: low-paid, low-skilled workers are the ones still expected to go to work, and they are more likely to die)

Here are the death rates for men. Basically managers and professionals have seen far fewer deaths; there are many factors here, some demographic/health related, but also those people are far more able to do their jobs from home. https://t.co/sB0APaUBtm

This seems to have quite a lot to do with exposure: the people in the most affected individual jobs are generally those who have had no choice but to keep working, and keep being exposed to members of the public. (And these "exposed" jobs are not well-paid jobs, by and large.) https://t.co/PVhim0300U

Important new data from the ONS out today looking at Covid-19 deaths by occupation. Key findings: social care workers seeing significantly raised levels of deaths, and people working in lowest-skilled jobs generally are the most vulnerable. https://t.co/wCTXlHL0P8

Data thread for those living in areas with a high % of middle-class jobs that can be done from home or are non-essential. Worth reading before you criticise those living in areas with a high % of production/caring/delivery jobs for "flouting lockdown".  https://t.co/fL5fMe6kOx
Anyway great investigative work by the band: @michaelgoodier on words and scraping and @joshrayman on viz.

In some areas people don't have a choice about working from home, or being able to choose not to work. Those tend to be areas with high level of "producing" jobs done in factories etc; more middle-class professional areas have locked down more, because they can.
I suspect that even if there's a correlation between e.g. Brexit voting (which I saw somewhere) and lower drops in workplace movement, the _causal_ factor is more likely to be something like this.
At the other end of the scale: workplace movement has dropped _least_ in areas with lots of skilled trades, elementary manual jobs, factory jobs and caring jobs. https://t.co/lFG0TyTkf0

Places with lots of professional, technical roles have seen workplace movement drop more. That make sense: these are often jobs that can be done at home, or aren't "essential" in the same way as e.g. producing and delivering food. https://t.co/vQA8hgdoXy
The higher in the chart a dot is, the more workplace mobility has reduced during the lockdown.
On these charts: dots are cities/conurbations/counties. The further to the right a "dot" is, the more reliant that area is on that type of job.

Why has movement around workplaces dropped in some places more than others during lockdown? Suggest it has nothing to do with people's beliefs/choices but rather to do with the jobs they have. @michaelgoodier plots movement levels v job types across the UK https://t.co/IXwmiFJi9t https://t.co/NZ6T8rLTg6

The gaps are a problem though and will not be closed in this way. The ONS data, while released much more slowly, will remain a better source of how many people actually died on particular days. But it's not much use to monitor a very dynamic situation like this.

The "daily deaths" will eventually catch up with the lag. When case numbers finally begin to fall, reported daily figure will be _higher_ than the number of actual deaths on a particular day. For now we're late reporting an increase; eventually we'll be late reporting a fall.

So there are two issues here:
1) The lag: the number of deaths _reported_ on a day won't match the number who _died_ on that day. It takes time to record a death.
2) The gaps: people are dying of Covid outside hospitals (e.g. in care homes) & without being tested.

To clarify:
The "daily total" being announced: deaths in hospitals, reported up to 5pm that day, of patients who tested+ for Covid
ONS figure: all deaths (in hosp or otherwise) that happened on that day & where Covid mentioned on death certificate.

The other thing that leaps out is the massive fall in neo-natal deaths. Here it is plotted as a single graph (6/6) https://t.co/TejScjfj9z
So in 1978, some 5,130 people aged 58 died, and just 4,158 aged 60. But then: there were far fewer 60 year olds around in the first place. (5/x).

Here we can see that the number of deaths rises with age - then suddenly drops before rising again. Why? Among other things it reflects a significant drop in the number of births during WW1. There were 340,000 more births in 1920 than there were in 1918. (4/x)

But of course the number of deaths at age x isn't just a function of life expectancy. It also matters how many people were born x years ago. This becomes more clear when we look at the figures for 1998, 1988 and 1978 (3/x) https://t.co/hQEUbLZM0z

Six years is a long time to work on a journalism project. Any digital unit thrives on constant evolution and new ideas. It's time to step aside - in @clairemilleruk and @AnnieGouk the unit has a brilliant leadership team and I can't wait to see what they do next. 12/12

Most of all though I wanted to say thanks to the team (past as well as present) for their brilliance, creativity and dedication. Our success has been their success far more than it has been mine. 11/12

I‚Äôd like to thank the editors and reporters across Reach titles: our aim has always been a collaboration between data insight and local expertise, and this could only ever work through partnership with you. 10/12
I‚Äôd like to say thanks to the editors and senior management at Reach that had the faith to start the team, allow us to pursue of our vision, and give us the resources to build so rapidly. 9/12

I‚Äôm proud of the impact we‚Äôve had within Reach, on the industry as a whole, and on the excellent data teams that have followed in our wake. I'm proud we've balanced quality & quantity and worked with the industry and readers we have - not the ones we'd want. 8/12

I remain steadfastly sceptical of journalism awards - but I am secretly extremely proud of the many national and international awards that both the team collectively, and it‚Äôs brilliant individual members, have racked up. 7/12
I‚Äôm proud of the innovation - the interactives, the gadgets, the tools that we‚Äôve built - which have had a profound and measurable affect on our audiences. 6/12
I‚Äôm proud of the many, many hundreds of public-interest front pages - the kind of thing people who don‚Äôt really read the news think don‚Äôt exist any more - that have come from this team. 5/12

I‚Äôm enormously proud of everything we‚Äôve done. I'm proud of the long-form data investigations but also the daily stream of data-based stories. I‚Äôm proud that most of our content is based on ideas; that we try to set rather than follow the agenda. 4/12
Since then - thanks to a lot of work and a hugely supportive company - we‚Äôve grown to become the UKs biggest dedicated data journalism team. 3/12

When we started back in 2013 - just me and @clairemilleruk - we nothing but a blank sheet of paper a vision of making data journalism an essential, daily part of mainstream regional and local news. 2/12
Personal news: after six amazing years I‚Äôve decided to leave the Reach Data Unit early in the new year. 1/12

I mean you can say this very strong link between age and voting (Labour in particular) is a new thing, a Corbyn thing - but it's not a 2019 thing, and not the story of the youth vote in 2019.
(The difference is, the Tories didn't benefit from a lower Labour vote share in the youngest age groups - the Lib Dems, SNP and Greens did.)

If you are looking at the YouGov poll and going "OH MY GOD LOOK HOW AGE DIVIDES US!", make sure you also look at the 2017 version. There IS a clear age split, but no more so than 2017, and Labour lost as much vote share in the youngest as oldest age groups this time (maybe more) https://t.co/y1ecpDbYPH

So what about pre-Corbyn? Here's the same chart for 2015. You can see Labour still won the youngest seats, but it was less dominant there. And while 2015 wasn't considered a "good" election for Labour, it actually did fairly well in those "middle-aged" seats. https://t.co/j6TMvcoLN9

It's a similar pattern, and Labour's dominance in the youngest seats (which tend to be highly urban and often in university cities like London, Manchester, Leeds, Sheffield, Bristol, etc) held up reasonably well. It lost more votes (versus the Tories) in "older" seats.

The "oldest" seats with more Labour than Tory voters - those red bars to the right - are all in Merseyside. The "youngest" seat won by the Tories was Bath - and though they got more votes than Labour, the Lib Dems actually won the seat. Now let's look at 2017: https://t.co/SsTzrcMWMe

The link between age and voting Labour or Conservative is really striking. Here's what happens if we line up all the seats in England, by average adult age, with the youngest on the left. Then we look at whether more people voted Labour (up bar) or Conservative (down). 1/x https://t.co/L7ROgliGqH

@alexhern @baeing Well, yes; but we currently have large towns serving major cities with irregular and unreliable bus services, which only get worse outside commuter hours. There's an awful lot to fix before we get to places where buses will never be a realistic option.

@alexhern @baeing Well, no. But neither is the crapness of public transport in most of the UK a function of geography. It could be far better, and should be far better, in towns and cities as well as villages.
@alexhern @baeing It isn't just villages that have a problem with regular public transport (or in some cases, any public transport at all).

@alexhern @baeing Efforts to disincentivise car use by making making the roads more jammed/worse is only going to have bad economic effects (and piss people off) if the only reason they are in the car in the first place is because there is no other way to get to where they need to be.

@alexhern @baeing I don't think anyone disagrees with that. But you can't just let roads go to ruin/not build any more _unless_ you provide a realistic public transport option _first_. And people need to understand just how far away we are from that, in most parts of the UK.

@alexhern (The amount it would cost to build rail infrastructure that would make it a reasonable public transport option for most or even many tasks, in most or even many parts of the country, is insane.)

@valstevens24 Guess it's a question of long-term balance, which I admit isn't easy. But simply building new "affordable rent" homes instead of social-rent homes, and counting them together against the same target doesn't seem helpful. Particularly when homeless is going up and up.

(Addendum: just been contacted by someone who points out (fairly) that there are _some_ places where AR can be cheaper than SR. This is true; it's unusual, but it does sometimes happen. On average, nationally, SR is much cheaper.)
Social rent levels are controlled by government. Affordable rent can be up to 80 per cent of local market rates. And 80 per cent of very expensive is still very expensive, for most people.

This, by the way, is one of the reasons I baulk when people talk of a generalised "housing shortage". It lets people off the hook because some data suggests there _isn't_ a generalised housing shortage. 

There is a shortage of the cheapest and most secure type of housing.

I'm going to continue banging on today about the fact both "affordable rent" and "social rent" are now counted together as types of "affordable housing". Social rent - what we used to call council housing - is more secure and on average 30% cheaper. And it's disappearing. https://t.co/nWvVt4QIgM

So is the overall boom in "affordable housing" in the last couple of years down to more "affordable rent" homes, or more social-rent homes? Very much the former. The number of social-rent homes being built has plummeted. (4/5) https://t.co/jGnr7jzHYt

They are _not_, however, the same thing as social rent homes - "council houses", in old money - which tend to be very much cheaper, and are also included in the overall figures. The @jrf_uk found "affordable" rented homes" were 30% more expensive than social rented homes. (3/5)

In 2011, the government introduced something called "affordable rent" - rent at up to 80% of local market rates. These "affordable rent" homes are counted in the overall figures for "affordable homes" in the graph above. (2/5)

@DataRemixed (I would say however that "likely to mislead" is a disqualifying vice. In the case of your original chart, I'd say the vice is more "not as clear as it could be in communicating all the relevant information". That's more negotiable.)
@DataRemixed That exactly as I'd see it - and saying this is not to allow people to scream "I WAS JUST BALANCING VIRTUES!" next to one of these https://t.co/ddcTdMlgz6

@DataRemixed I'm not a fan of this particular graph, although I'm not sure much is lost. (The data labels are useful in that regard.) I doubt it's going to make line graphs suddenly Huge On The Internet. But the issues are fascinating.
@DataRemixed Personally, I'd say that's a fine place to be.
@DataRemixed There are obviously minimal requirements (accuracy, for example, or not being misleading) but that doesn't mean we might not be balancing virtues.

@DataRemixed If a million people see this because it's shared widely, but only 50,000 saw a different version that uses a shared x axis - which is better serving its purpose (which is presumably to share an important piece of information)?

@DataRemixed After all, the graph isn't "wrong" in any way; and the intuitive thing it seems to show at first glance is, indeed, what it is showing. It's not the most precise way of doing it, and I'd be surprised if loads of "non-data-people" love it, but who knows?

@DataRemixed A lot of answers to your question are pointing out that if you do things this way there's some "information loss", which is obviously true. But the question whether "non-data-people" respond well to this, feel their intuitively "get" it, are minded to share it - they matter, too

(And, by the by, none of the deep structural issues facing the industry will be solved by people pointing at journalists and screaming "Do better!" We can see what your reading habits are...)

(Which is why our preferred end-point should always be living in a society that financially sustains its own journalism. Journalism that pays its own way is a journalism that isn't beholden to anyone else.)
(There are also questions, with private funding, as to "which businesses?" Any business? What if the stories they are paying for end up a bit close to home?)
To a large extent, those are three separate issues and we (society generally, not "journalism") need to think about each one.

I always think there are 3 things we need to address when people complain about a supposed lack of public-interest reporting.
-We need reporters doing such reporting
-We need trusted distribution channels
-We need audiences who genuinely care about (will read about) such things.

I'm a big fan of the LDR scheme. Have no problem with at attracting private funding as long as a) this is on top of robust public/BBC/taxpayer funding, and b) it is genuinely sustainable.

Part of the problem is an increasing trend for some people (including some journalists) to see journalists not as skilled and trained tradespeople who do a vital job, but as Batman.

(I guess in some contexts the former role is less significant now so much more is digitised and televised, but still: journalists have access others don't, and are a signpost to "important" happenings. Plus e.g. court cases are still not widely available to "view".)

Just don't see a tension between "Journalists should simply report what's happening/being said!" and "Journalists should analyse/scrutinise what's happening/being said!" They are both aspects of journalism, good journalists do both & I wouldn't want a journalism than only did one

Manchester is not Manchester city centre, and the housing problems facing most people in Manchester are _not_ the housing problems of Manchester city centre. (10/10)
That doesn't mean some things shouldn't be protected, but it does mean Manchester will never been some sort of industrial museum. (9/x)

As for the architectural consequences: well, okay, they are overbuilding Angel Meadows and as someone who live there a long time & love it, that's a shame. But in general Manchester is a pragmatic city, a functional city; it is not sentimental or vain about its appearance. (8/x)

The pressure should be on the authorities to find more effective ways of taking a bigger share of the profits from the city-centre boom, and redistributing it to boost communities and housing in other parts of Manchester. Take money from those who buy-to-not-let (7/x)

How "affordable" can you make city centre flats, anyway? At the moment "affordable" is defined as 80% of market value. Eighty per cent of something completely unaffordable is still completely unaffordable to most people. So who are you helping? (6/x)

You might say the solution is more affordable housing, and perhaps more social housing. Very well. Where? City centre flats? Or something more affordable and family-friendly in parts of the city that need regenerating and are seeing no private investment? (5/x)

At the same time, we've seen homelessness levels in the city _as a whole_ rise back towards their mid 2000s-peak. Why? Many reasons, including a housing benefit freeze at the very time private rents have been rising. (4/x)

And it isn't as if the residential culture of the city centre has changed. It never used to have a residential culture at all. Virtually no one lived in the city centre two decades ago. City centre living is brand new. (3/x)
1) Whenever people write about Manchester, they _always_ write as if the city centre is the whole of Manchester. It isn't. It's quite a small part of the city, actually. (2/x)

So we start with this scatterplot and a couple of arbitrary definitions: 
Marginal = <10,000 majority
Very marginal = <5,000 majority
Strong leave = >60% voted to leave
Weaker leave = 50% to 60% voted to leave

@umarhassan96 Animating the line is one solution but my general point is if we're animating, we don't need a _line_ at all. We represent time not as an x-axis, but as time (e.g. a one second delay = passing of one month). So we can do e.g. this (or something much better!) https://t.co/kmuMWE6zr0
And that's our job.

In general people shy away from this kind of presentation not just because it's a bit harder to do, but also there's a weird bias: IT'S TOO EASY TO UNDERSTAND! IT DOESN'T LOOK AS COMPLEX AND MATHS-Y AS A GRAPH!

@Effy_Yeomans I've passed the story and analysis we've done to the MEN; will be interesting to see what the council say if the MEN decide to use the story, and approach them for comment. Many councils argue they already take large numbers of refugees and asylum seekers under other programmes.

It's also important to point out this is only one scheme - introduced in response to the Syrian crisis - by which refugees can enter the UK. Many councils already host large numbers of refugees from around the world under e.g. the government's preferred "dispersal" model.

The scheme is voluntary - councils don't have to participate at all. The aim of the VPRS was to resettle 20,000 refugees by the time the scheme closes in 2020. By March this year the achieved figure was 17,051.

I've been doing some analysis on the number of refugees from the Syrian conflict resettled in the UK under the Vulnerable Persons Resettlement Scheme since 2014. It's fair to say some cities have embraced the scheme more enthusiastically than others. https://t.co/HXkVHBKXeI

RT @davidottewell: Doctors surgeries are a major issue right now. I've been looking at some of the data that might explain why.

*Short thr‚Ä¶

What's more worrying is that the number of patients per FTE doctor has gone up from 2,098 to 2,181: each full-time GP has responsibility for 83 extra patients since Sep 2017. The government says it's spending on recruitment - but right now that means pressure on appointments. https://t.co/0Tjf7oD5xE

That isn't necessarily a bad thing. Economies of scale mean backroom savings can, theoretically, mean more money going to patient care. Often mergers are chiefly administrative and don't take away actual buildings. However...
The average number of patients-per-surgery has thus risen from 7,943 to 8,550. https://t.co/bx9eSo7by2

Then there's the fact that a number of GP surgeries - which are effectively mini-businesses whose client is the NHS - are finding it hard to survive. Mergers and closures mean we have 394 fewer surgeries than 18 months ago. https://t.co/Np5I5iIs52
At the same time the number of registered patients continues to rise apace - by more than a million in the time period we're considering. https://t.co/hBBbQ6j3QI

Well, yes; but they are working _less time_. Many choose to be locums & do only a certain number of shifts a week. They don't want the hassle of running a practice, or working full time. The number of full-time equivalent GPs, therefore, has actually dropped by 547. https://t.co/CQpmD3JacM
First: the absolute number of fully-trained GPs working in surgeries in England has actually risen - by 242 - over the last 18 months. That's good, right? https://t.co/6aRmjXG4q3

Doctors surgeries are a major issue right now. I've been looking at some of the data that might explain why.

*Short thread*
Well, yes. But they are working fewer hours. When we look at the number of full-time equivalents, the number of GPs has fallen by 547 over the same period. https://t.co/0mlWWxDWsy
First: the total number of fully qualified and fully trained GPs has actually gone up (by 242) in the last 18 months. So that's good, right? https://t.co/O7wTL9nsie

What drugs are schoolgirls and schoolboys most likely to have tried? For boys it's cannabis, for girls it's solvents. (Caveat: they are _all_ very unlikely to have tried any at all). https://t.co/2DzS1PzegK

Are e-cigarettes part of the problem or part of the solution? Hard to say. Some 27% of boys and 23 per cent of girls said they had used them in 2018. But only 3% of boys and 1% of girls were regular users; and it's not clear whether they'd be smoking if not vaping.

Aaaaagh (9/9)

I think there's still an awful lot of value in providing cleaned up, regional and local summaries along with the national summaries. Of course we want the full open data, too: but _only_ publishing the open data is a recipe for misunderstanding. (8/x)

That's a lot of extra charges and completely skews the percentage, too. Why is it different to the 403,221 figure? There's absolutely no way of knowing. How was the 403,221 figure derived, anyway? So how are we supposed to proceed? (7/x)

Well, with a bit of work you can extract the information for all forces from the open data tables. So that's good. Except when you add up the total number of charges in 2019/20, you get this: (6/x) https://t.co/rbXYYryJnE
...and says this means the % of crimes resulting in someone being charged fell from 9.1% to 7.8%. That's an important and interesting development. So what's the local picture? (5/x)

But the biggest problem is the lack of cleaning can lead to completely baffling discrepancies. Today, for example, I'm looking at crime outcomes. The national release says the number of people charged for crimes fell from 442,707 in 17/18 to 403,221 in 18/19... (4/x)
Why? Well, for one thing not everyone is a data journalist, or an expert in spreadsheets, or able to use R or other languages to extract the relevant local information. (3/x)
This is good, in many ways - it means we get loads of really detailed local data. But I'd suggest it remains best practice to put out cleaned up local data, too. (2/x)

Today's data journalism #ddj whinge. So there's a tendency now for statistical bodies to publish national summary data, nicely cleaned and accompanied by explanatory reports, and then just dump out all the detailed local stuff as "open data" in huge csv files. (1/x)

New official Valuation Office figures on average rents came out today. I've done this quick map, which shows _something_ of a geographical split! Interesting to see Bristol has "London prices"; Manchester, Trafford and Exeter have "Home Counties" prices. https://t.co/lcDoMPd8eX

You could also look at it like this: house prices are 70x higher than in 1968, while income is 30x higher. So take your current income, double it, and add another third: you're basically in the same situation vis-a-vis buying a house as someone from 1968.
https://t.co/pvbb2bjJAa

Couple of things stand out: 1) it wasn't until the late 1990s that the link between earnings and house prices was rapidly and substantially broken. Since the mid-2000s houses have been unaffordable for very many people. 2) The banking crash didn't, in fact, "change everything".

House Price Index out today and guess what? Houses are still really expensive. Here's a longer-term look: on this graph, both house prices and annual income are set at 100 in 1968. This is how they've changed since then. https://t.co/LZao76sX6h

RT @davidottewell: Does anyone else use the MHCLG local government finance figures and find they never pass a basic "smell test"? Take this‚Ä¶
It's a shame such an apparently rich source of stories - and a way of holding important public authorities, and the government, to account - is shrouded in so much _doubt_. (6/6)

If you're interested in just one or two councils then fine - you've got a lead, something to chase up. But if you're interested in the aggregate figure, or comparing councils: who has the time to chase up every single one? (5/x)

Now you might think: well, that sounds possible. Unlikely, but possible, and definitely worth chasing up. But then what of this? North Tyneside council apparently has ¬£0 in banks, ¬£0 in building societies and ¬£0 in funds. Is that plausible? (4/x) https://t.co/ZDeLUDJWnp
Manchester council has precisely ¬£0 in invested in money market and externally managed funds, as it did in 2014. (3/x)

These figures, which I've compiled and cleaned, are in thousands. So they imply e.g. that Stockport council had ¬£19m in banks and building societies in March 14, but precisely ¬£0 in banks and building societies now. (2/x)

Does anyone else use the MHCLG local government finance figures and find they never pass a basic "smell test"? Take this for instance: I'm looking at councils taking investments out of banks & building societies and putting them into (higher-risk) funds. #ddj (1/x) https://t.co/PJQzlx0jpy
